{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Gizzle | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_upright = | image_size = | landscape = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank --> | alt = | caption = | background = solo_singer | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = Glenda Proby | alias = Lady G Da Real Deal | birth_date = {{Birth based on age as of date|28|2016|9|6}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[United States]] | origin = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date first) --> | death_place = | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = | instrument = | years_active = 2007–present | label = [[The GZL Company]] | associated_acts = {{Plainlist| * [[Puff Daddy]] * [[Ty Dolla Sign]] * [[Lupe Fiasco]] * [[Delta Goodrem]] * [[G-Eazy]] * [[Boyz Noize]] }} | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} or {{Official URL}} --> | module = | module2 = | module3 = }} '''Glenda Proby''' (born 1987/1988),<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/features/profile/9945-meet-the-queer-female-mc-whos-writing-your-favorite-rappers-songs/|title=Meet Gizzle, the Queer Female MC Who’s Writing Your Favorite Rappers’ Songs|last=Aku|first=Timmhotep|date=September 6, 2016|website=Pitchfork|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 26, 2018}}</ref> better known by her stage names '''Gizzle''' and '''Lady G''', is an American [[hip hop]] [[songwriter]] and [[rapper]]. Beginning her career as a [[ghostwriter]] for [[Lil' Fizz]] and [[Snoop Dogg]] in 2008, she has since collaborated with a number of prominent artists, particularly [[Puff Daddy]] and [[Ty Dolla Sign]]. She made her first appearance as a featured artist in 2015, on "You Can Be My Lover" from Puff Daddy's album ''[[MMM (Money Making Mitch)|MMM]]''[[MMM (Money Making Mitch)|,]] and released her debut [[mixtape]] ''7 Days in Atlanta'' in 2017.
== Early career == From [[South Los Angeles]], Proby showed a talent for writing from a young age, composing poetry and lengthy letters to her father when he was in jail.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://kulturehub.com/gizzle-artist-feature/|title=Gizzle, the LA songwriter behind some of your favorite hits, is going solo|last=Easy|first=Claude J.|date=October 6, 2017|website=KultureHub|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 26, 2018}}</ref> She started rapping as a teenager under the stage name ''Lady G Da Real Deal'', regularly attending [[freestyle rap]] events in Los Angeles and [[San Bernardino County, California|San Bernardino county]]. She recorded a [[Demo (music)|demo]] with Rhythm D of [[Ruthless Records]]<ref name=":0" /> and was offered a [[recording contract]] at the age of 17. However, she was encouraged by her manager, Cudda Love, to pursue songwriting for others instead.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.laweekly.com/music/south-la-rapper-gizzle-has-ghostwritten-for-all-the-dudes-now-shes-writing-for-herself-7901167|title=South L.A. Rapper Gizzle Has Ghostwritten for All the Dudes. Now She's Writing for Herself|last=Jones|first=Tracy|date=February 6, 2017|work=L.A. Weekly|access-date=July 26, 2018}}</ref>
In 2007, she gained her first writing credit on the [[Lil' Fizz]] track "Beds". She was then invited by producer [[Teddy Riley]] to write for [[Snoop Dogg|Snoop Dogg's]] 2008 album [[Ego Trippin'|''Ego Trippin''<nowiki/>']].<ref name=":0" /> She is credited on the tracks "Gangsta Like Me" and "Can't Say Goodbye",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#ace/writer/426541370/PROBY%20GLENDA%20R|title=Proby Glenda R|last=|first=|date=|website=ACE Repertory|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 26, 2018}}</ref> both of which were regularly highlighted in positive reviews of the album.<ref name="Rolling Stone">{{cite journal|last=Edwards|first=Gavin|date=March 20, 2008|title=Snoop Dogg: Ego Trippin'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/19002772/review/19059601/ego_trippin|deadurl=yes|journal=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=|volume=|pages=63–64|issn=0035-791X|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308152956/http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/19002772/review/19059601/ego_trippin|archivedate=March 8, 2008|via=|magazine=|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/article/2008/03/07/ego-trippin/|title=Ego Trippin'|last=Watson|first=Margeaux|date=March 7, 2008|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|access-date=July 26, 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/11277-ego-trippin/|title=Snoop Dogg: Ego Trippin' Album Review|last=Breihan|first=Tom|date=March 14, 2008|website=Pitchfork|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/ego-trippin-mw0000751573|title=Ego Trippin' – Snoop Dogg|last=Jeffries|first=David|date=|website=AllMusic|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2008/03/11/snoop-dogg-ego-trippin-review|title=Snoop Dogg – Ego Trippin' Review|last=|first=|authors=Spence D.|date=March 11, 2008|website=IGN|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 26, 2018}}</ref>
[[Ego Trippin'|<nowiki/>]]
[[Ego Trippin'|<nowiki/>]]
[[Ego Trippin'|<nowiki/>]][[Ego Trippin'|<nowiki/>]][[Ego Trippin'|<nowiki/>]]
== Ghostwriting == Since her early work with Riley and Snoop Dogg, Proby has become a prolific hip hop [[ghostwriter]], working with prominent artists including [[Kanye West]], [[Nicki Minaj]], [[Meek Mill]], [[Boosie Badazz]], [[Kevin Gates]], [[G-Eazy]], [[Iggy Azalea]], [[Trey Songz]], [[Travis Scott]] and [[T.I.]] Two of her most frequent collaborators are [[Ty Dolla Sign]], who she has worked with since 2008, and [[Puff Daddy]] (Sean Combs), whose albums ''[[MMM (album)|MMM]]'' and ''[[No Way Out 2]]'' she contributed to extensively.<ref name=":0" />
Unusually for a female writer, Proby writes primarily for male rappers, but has been praised for successfully "getting inside the heads" of artists and working closely with them to compose songs that match their personal styles. She is also one of very few prominent [[queer]] women in the hip hop industry. Ty Dolla Sign has stated that this is an advantage in the often hypermasculine and hypersexualised world of hip hop, "you know she gets both sides ’cause Gizzle got bitches too!"<ref name=":0" />
== Solo career == Proby began performing her own songs under the stage name Gizzle in 2011, posting several videos on her [[YouTube]] channel.<ref name=":0" /> In 2015, she was credited as a featured artist on "You Can Be My Lover" from Puff Daddy's album ''MMM.'' The following year, her appearance in the video for the track, as an unexpected "butch lesbian leading the song, rapping about hollering at women in the middle of a misogynistic smorgasbord,"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://themuse.jezebel.com/progress-gizzle-a-queer-mc-rapped-about-boning-women-1768290794|title=Progress: Gizzle, a Queer MC, Rapped About Boning Women In a Puffy Video & No One Blinked An Eye|last=Coker|first=Hillary Crosley|date=March 31, 2016|work=The Muse|access-date=July 26, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> became a breakout performance for Gizzle.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.colorlines.com/articles/after-writing-rap-hits-can-queer-female-mc-break-mainstream|title=After Writing Rap Hits, Can This Queer Female MC Break Into the Mainstream? {{!}} Colorlines|last=Rao|first=Sameer|date=September 7, 2016|work=Colorlines|access-date=July 26, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
Gizzle released her debut [[mixtape]], ''7 Days in Atlanta'', in January 2017.<ref name=":2" /> The EP was produced in a single, week-long trip to [[Atlanta]], with one of seven songs being recorded each day. Gizzle plans to continue this concept with further ''7 Days'' mixtapes recorded in other cities, including Los Angeles, [[Philadelphia]] and [[Denver]].<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.undergroundhiphop.com/magazine/interview/gizzle-takes-on-the-rap-game/|title=Gizzle Steps Out Of The Ghostwriter Shadows To Take on the Rap Game|last=Orcutt|first=KC|date=|website=Underground Hip Hop|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 26, 2018}}</ref> ''Revolt'' described the EP as "a serious reminder of why [Gizzle] is one of the best in the business."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://revolt.tv/stories/2017/01/31/music-gizzle-7-days-atlanta-ep-070037b417|title=New Music: Gizzle, '7 Days in Atlanta' EP|last=Britt|first=Yazid|date=January 31, 2017|website=REVOLT TV|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 26, 2018}}</ref>
She is also working on a debut album, titled ''The Jump'', to be released in 2018.<ref name=":2" /> She was featured on the [[Lupe Fiasco]] track "Jump", from ''[[Drogas Light]]'', in 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7752681/lupe-fiasco-jump-video-gizzle|title=Lupe Fiasco & Gizzle Link Up for 'Jump' Video|work=Billboard|access-date=July 26, 2018}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | name =Henry Alexander Davidson | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1905|5|27}} | birth_place =[[Newark, New Jersey]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1973|8|23|1905|5|27}} | death_place =[[East Orange, New Jersey]] | other_names = | order = | office = [[Director of Essex County Hospital Center]]| term_start =1957 | term_end =1969 | appointed = | predecessor = | successor = }}
'''Henry Alexander Davidson''' (May 27, 1905 - August 23, 1973) was an American [[physician]], a psychiatric administrator, and a proponent of [[forensic psychiatry]].<ref name=obit/>
==Biography== Davidson was born on May 27, 1905 in [[Newark, New Jersey]], the son of a physician.<ref name=obit/>
He earned his undergraduate degree at the [[Columbia University]] in [[Manhattan, New York City]]. He attended the [[Jefferson Medical College]] in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and received his M.D. in 1928. In 1931, he received an M.S. in [[neuropsychiatry]] from the [[University of Pennsylvania]]. He interned at [[Newark Beth Israel Medical Center|Beth Israel Medical Center]] in Newark, New Jersey from 1928 to 1929, and was a resident at the [[Philadelphia Orthopedic Hospital and Infirmary for Nervous Diseases]] from 1931 to 1932. He later became a diplomate in [[psychiatry]] given by the [[American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology]].
Davidson was in private practice in Newark for about ten years. With the start of [[World War II]], he entered military service in 1941 and served in the South Pacific. He left the military in 1947 with the rank of Major. He entered the civil service at the [[Veterans Administration]] in Newark and worked at the central office in Washington, DC from 1950 to 1954. He then became assistant superintendent of the [[Essex County Overbrook Hospital]], a large [[mental hospital]] in New Jersey. He became the superintendent and stayed for twelve years. When he left the hospital in 1969, he returned to his private practice, consulting, and lecturing.
Davidson lectured on medical legal matters at the Columbia University and the [[University of Virginia]]. He was a president of the [[New Jersey Psychiatric Association]], president of the [[New Jersey Academy of Medicine]], and president of the [[New Jersey Medico Legal Society]]. He served as parliamentarian of the [[American Psychiatric Association]] (APA) and wrote on parliamentary procedures. He was editor of ''The Journal of the New Jersey Medical Society'' for 32 years, and was an editor of the ''American Journal of Psychiatry''.
He died ay his home, 276 Prospect Street in [[East Orange, New Jersey]] on August 23, 1973 of [[coronary thrombosis]].<ref name=obit>{{cite news |author= |title= Dr. Henry A. Davidson Is Dead; A Psychiatrist and Author, 68|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1973/08/24/archives/dr-henry-a-davidson-is-dead-a-psychiatrist-and-author-68.html?_r=0 |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=August 24, 1973 }}</ref>
==Publications== *Davidson, Henry A. “Mental Hygiene and the General Hospital,” ''The Journal of the Medical Society of New Jersey'' (1941): 173-176. *Davidson, Henry A. “Orientation to Psychosomatics,” ''Military Surgeon'' (1947): 47-50. *Davidson, Henry A. ''A Short History of Chess''. New York: Greenberg [1949]. *Davidson, Henry A. ''Forensic Psychiatry''. New York: Ronald, 1952. *Davidson, Henry A. ''Guide to Medical Writing: A Practical Manual for Physicians, Dentists, Nurses, Pharmacists''. New York: Ronald Press, 1957. *Davidson, Henry A. ''The World of Doctor Whatsisname''. Washington: American Psychiatric Association, 1961.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *Braceland, Francis J. “Henry Alexander Davidson, 1905-1973,” ''American Journal of Psychiatry'' 131(1) (1974): 10. *Cowen, David L. ''Medicine and Health in New Jersey: A History''. Princeton, NJ: Van Nostrand, 1964.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Davidson, Henry Alexander}} [[Category:1905 births]] [[Category:1973 deaths]] [[Category:American forensic psychiatrists]] [[Category:Physicians from Newark, New Jersey]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Jefferson Medical College alumni]] [[Category:University of Pennsylvania alumni]] [[Category:Columbia University faculty]] [[Category:University of Virginia School of Medicine faculty]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Deaths from thrombosis]]

The '''innovation butterfly''' is a [[metaphor]] that describes how seemingly minor perturbations (disturbances or changes) to project plans in a system connecting markets, demand, product features, and a firm's capabilities can steer the project, or an entire portfolio of projects, down an irreversible path in terms of technology and market evolution.
==Origins== The metaphor was developed by researchers Anderson and Joglekar.<ref name="SysThkr">Anderson, E.G. Jr. and Joglekar, N.R. (2007). "Chasing the Innovation Butterfly with 'Systems Thinking'", ''The Systems Thinker'', 18(9): 7-9.</ref> It was conceived as a specific instance of the more general '[[butterfly effect]]' encountered in [[chaos theory]].
==How it works== The innovation butterfly arises because many innovation systems are made up of a large number of elements that interact with each other via several non-linear [[feedback loop]]s containing embedded delays, thus constituting a [[complex system]].<ref>Sterman, J.D. (1994). "Learning in and about Complex Systems", ''System Dynamics Review'', 10(2-3): 291-330.</ref>
Perturbations can come from decisions made within the firm or from those made by its competitors, or they can result from external forces such as government legislation or environmental regulations, or unexpected spikes in the [[Price of petroleum|price of oil]]. How the innovation system evolves as a result of the innovation butterfly can lead ultimately to an innovative firm's success or failure.
Complex systems, in domains such as [[physics]], [[biology]], or [[sociology]], are known to be prone to both [[path dependence]] and [[emergent behavior]]. What makes the behavior of the innovation butterfly different is market selection, along with biases in individual and group decision making within distributed innovation settings, may influence the emergent behavior. Furthermore, managers in most fields of business endeavor to reduce uncertainty in order to better manage risk. In innovation settings, however, because success is based upon [[creativity]], managers must actively embrace [[uncertainty]]. This leads to a management conundrum because innovation managers and management systems must encourage the potential for a butterfly effect but then must also learn how to cope with its aftermath.<ref name="Joglekar 2007 pp. 7-9">Anderson and Joglekar (2007), pp. 7-9.</ref><ref>Anderson, Edward G and Nitin R. Joglekar. (2012). The Innovation Butterfly: Managing Emergent Opportunities and Risks During Distributed Innovation. Springer (Understanding Complex Systems Series)"</ref>
How innovation butterflies are 'chased' is highly managerially relevant.<ref>Anderson, Edward G. and Nitin Joglekar (2005). A Hierarchical Modeling Framework for Product Development Planning. ''Production and Operations Management'', 14 (3): 344-361.</ref> Most butterflies end up 'merely' consuming a considerable amount of time and resources within a project, or for an innovation portfolio, within a firm. However, some butterflies can also unleash [[Regime change|regime-altering]] emergent outcomes within an entire industry segment.<ref>Garud, R. and Karnøe, P. 2001 ‘Path Creation as a Process of Mindful Deviation’. In Path Dependence and Creation, R. Garud and P. Karnøe (eds.) Lawrence Erlbaum Associates: 1-38.</ref> Moreover, once these emergent outcomes begin to mature, and in some instances lead to [[disruptive innovation]]s, they become extremely difficult to manage,<ref>Christensen, Clayton M. (1997). The Innovator's Dilemma : When New Technologies Cause Great Firms to Fail. Harvard Business Press.</ref> Hence, shaping the innovation system before potential innovation butterfly's effects completely emerge is critical.<ref name="Joglekar 2007 pp. 7-9"/>
==See also== *[[Volatility, uncertainty, complexity and ambiguity]] (VUCA)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Research literature== ===Books=== *Anderson, Edward G. Jr. and Nitin R. Joglekar (2012). [[The Innovation Butterfly: Managing Emergent Opportunities and Risks During Distributed Innovation.]] Springer (Understanding Complex Systems Series). [http://csc.ucdavis.edu/~chaos/courses/ncaso/Readings/Chaos_SciAm1986/Chaos_SciAm1986.html Online version] *Christensen, Clayton M. (1997). The Innovator's Dilemma : When New Technologies Cause Great Firms to Fail. Harvard Business Press.
[[Category:Causality]] [[Category:Economic problems]] [[Category:Innovation]] [[Category:Emergence]]
